fc86d77d6e7f42af90b3ba3a7fb99be7 (15:31): DavidHKMrPowers, sounds like you want a fully functional distro that you can extend
fc86d77d6e7f42af90b3ba3a7fb99be7 (15:31): DavidHKMrPowers, how much linux experience do you have?
702eef483f5b589321f3baec1fe96af6 (15:32): daMaestro : i don't know linux. I tried to install linux 7,8,fedora but only succeeded with 7. i installed something like webmin for web hosting
fc86d77d6e7f42af90b3ba3a7fb99be7 (15:32): DavidHKMrPowers, fedora and centos are good choices
fc86d77d6e7f42af90b3ba3a7fb99be7 (15:33): centos should fill your needs better then fedora.. because fedora needs more maintenace
fc86d77d6e7f42af90b3ba3a7fb99be7 (15:33): however.. fedora core 5 has things like mysql 5 and apache 2.2.2
fc86d77d6e7f42af90b3ba3a7fb99be7 (15:33): while centos has mysql 4.1.20 and apache 1.0.54
fc86d77d6e7f42af90b3ba3a7fb99be7 (15:34): webmin is a good software.. but security is a question with it
fc86d77d6e7f42af90b3ba3a7fb99be7 (15:34): so either don't leave it running.. or setup apache to secure it also
fc86d77d6e7f42af90b3ba3a7fb99be7 (15:34): (in other words run webmin from apache not its own server)
702eef483f5b589321f3baec1fe96af6 (15:35): daMaestro : fedora 5 build-in apache, mysql won't work for me because i won't know how to configure them...
fc86d77d6e7f42af90b3ba3a7fb99be7 (15:35): fedora core 5 has the mysql-administrator gui
fc86d77d6e7f42af90b3ba3a7fb99be7 (15:35): it is nice

702eef483f5b589321f3baec1fe96af6 (15:37): daMaestro : i concern about the security issue much, because i won't know how to configure apache to make it secure. so if i install centos/fedora with a apache , would i be able to start using http server without fine tuning ?
fc86d77d6e7f42af90b3ba3a7fb99be7 (15:37): yes
fc86d77d6e7f42af90b3ba3a7fb99be7 (15:37): and fedora and centos have SELinux enabled by default

30c03b8e79ec8ce163676751ccbf5c2b (15:38): i'm looking for a mod_rewrite or mod_proxy rule set which redirects direct calls with a uri of only 'null' or just '7' to display (via proxy or redirect) to a different url
30c03b8e79ec8ce163676751ccbf5c2b (15:38): i've read a lot of mod_xxxx rules over the years but I'm baffled on how to match and redirect requests only for resource / or null to a separate url
fc86d77d6e7f42af90b3ba3a7fb99be7 (15:38): fajita, rewriterule

b0a90be919a9f920bb8ad2caca4e91f0 (15:38): daMaestro: rewriterule is http://httpd.apache.org/docs-2.0/mod/mod_rewrite.html#rewriterule or http://httpd.apache.org/docs/mod/mod_rewrite.html#rewriterule or http://httpd.apache.org/docs/mod/mod_rewrite.html#rewritelog or tricky, because .htaccess RewriteRule acts differently than httpd.conf
b0a90be919a9f920bb8ad2caca4e91f0 (15:38): ..(RTFM!)
fc86d77d6e7f42af90b3ba3a7fb99be7 (15:38): fajita, proxypass
b0a90be919a9f920bb8ad2caca4e91f0 (15:38): daMaestro: proxypass is http://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.0/mod/mod_proxy.html#proxypass
fc86d77d6e7f42af90b3ba3a7fb99be7 (15:38): kracker, ^
fc86d77d6e7f42af90b3ba3a7fb99be7 (15:38): kracker, so.. just if the default document is requested? so www.domain.com/
fc86d77d6e7f42af90b3ba3a7fb99be7 (15:39): and not www.domain.com/something
30c03b8e79ec8ce163676751ccbf5c2b (15:39): specificly i'm looking to take (and only take) / and redirect to /welcome (no root browsing of /)
fc86d77d6e7f42af90b3ba3a7fb99be7 (15:39): rewriterule ^/$
fc86d77d6e7f42af90b3ba3a7fb99be7 (15:39): ^ start of uri $ end of url
fc86d77d6e7f42af90b3ba3a7fb99be7 (15:39): err uri*
30c03b8e79ec8ce163676751ccbf5c2b (15:39): nods, i do know that much of mod_rewrite/regex
30c03b8e79ec8ce163676751ccbf5c2b (15:40): but i lost / failed to find the next part
fc86d77d6e7f42af90b3ba3a7fb99be7 (15:40): rewriterule ^/$ /welcome
30c03b8e79ec8ce163676751ccbf5c2b (15:40): the redirect or (idea mod_proxy) display of /welcome instead of /
fc86d77d6e7f42af90b3ba3a7fb99be7 (15:40): rewriterule ^/$ /welcome [P]
fc86d77d6e7f42af90b3ba3a7fb99be7 (15:40): proxy it ^
30c03b8e79ec8ce163676751ccbf5c2b (15:41): fully
30c03b8e79ec8ce163676751ccbf5c2b (15:41): well i'll try that now
fc86d77d6e7f42af90b3ba3a7fb99be7 (15:41): not redirect as in: rewriterule ^/$ /welcome
30c03b8e79ec8ce163676751ccbf5c2b (15:42): daMaestro, thank you!
30c03b8e79ec8ce163676751ccbf5c2b (15:42): that' rocks simple esc!
30c03b8e79ec8ce163676751ccbf5c2b (15:43): those snippets are getting written down
30c03b8e79ec8ce163676751ccbf5c2b (15:43): it's so simple, boy was i way off in my efforts (i was copy/paste scripting again and using wrong aproch)

fc86d77d6e7f42af90b3ba3a7fb99be7 (16:05): no.. you don't know.. or no it does not?
